Message.Title: $ 240 today would be nice
Message.Msg: I'd take profits if we get there today

"You're right. Stocks aren't manipulated." Or let's say we hear how much the are for some reason only when it goes up a lot and shorts are losing money, very seldom when the opposite is happening. "And, you can try to discredit me all you want." Not hard to do as ignorant as you are of so many things. "I have a multiple year track record" You have zero years with Amazon which explains your eagerness to lose your shirt here. Nobody cares what you did against weaker and lesser stocks. You think you are the only guy who lost all his previous gains trying to short Amazon? I'll give you credit. You are a better hack than most of the paid short shills. Plus you did not brag to us about nanotech in the last post which means maybe you realize how much dumber those boasts make your already dumb posts seem.

"It is investion TONS of money in lockers..." Define "tons". Is it a few thousand bucks? Sounds like it is a very small program so far. (See below). "so that consumers can drive to pick up merchandise at the lockers instead of WalMart which has equal or better pricing on most items" Price has been debated enough here, but WalMart simply has a much smaller selection which is the whole problem about brick and mortar and why Amazon has taken so much share away from them. A lot of media or book titles are not sold by WalMart even if your claims about price were true." -------- About Lockers: "I haven’t had a chance to drive down to the Valley to see the lockers for myself (bad journalist!), but I was able to order a book for delivery to the San Carlos location, so they appear to be up-and-running. The interface for delivering to a locker is a bit wonky right now, because you can’t set an Amazon Locker as your default address, so you have to go in and manually select it each time. That, along with the limited locations, suggests this is still very much an experiment. But it’s an experiment that’s growing" http://techcrunch.com/2012/07/30/amazon-lockers-silicon-valley/

Nemesis: Tons being more than zero and more than it should in a fundamentally flawed concept. Everything AMZN is now doing will drive up fixed investment, increase minimum efficient scale (only for AMZN, not for other players) and drive down ROIC. It is the wrong set of strategic moves. Time will prove me right. But, you keep loading up pal...

Topic.Title: Long slow decline to $180 has started

Message.Msg: But even a pps of $130 would give AMZN a PE of almost 160 using the current ttm earnings! That's still WAY TOO HIGH for a low margin retailer with crap earnings!
It's tiring, isn't it? You dance, dance, and dance, and AMZN is down only slightly in three days while she shot up 18 points in a day last week. Tomorrow, she'll go up 10+ points.

"Tons being more than zero" OK. Hyperbole befits a paid short shill like you. "a fundamentally flawed concept." Yeah, so was selling books online. Shorts claimed people only liked to buy books in real book stores, the feel and smell of paper and ink and so forth. To shorts, everything indiscriminately becomes a flawed concept once they've gone short. So what use could your opinion be to anyone? "Everything AMZN is now doing will drive up fixed investment, increase minimum efficient scale (only for AMZN, not for other players) and drive down ROIC." Yes, until the increased profit and cashflow drive ROIC back up to new record highs again. Will dumb shorts like you never learn? ROIC: 3Q05 __ 44% 3Q06 __ 23% 4Q07 __ 55% "only for AMZN, not for other players" Even in the near term, BKS is at -6.4%, BBY 0.7%. I'm sure they'd like to hear your theory on how what Amazon does does not effect their ROIC. "It is the wrong set of strategic moves." Take it from him, folks. After all, he worked in nanotech (maybe as a janitor?) before. Great training ground for becoming an expert in retail. He knows more than Bezos, and the data they mine from 180 million customers. That's why he went short at around $180 before. And if he screws up he'll just say he is going away to "refocus". Get the code?
Keep trying Nemesis. You really are desperate, aren't you?
"ROIC: 3Q05 __ 44% 3Q06 __ 23% 4Q07 __ 55%" Why do you switch from 3Q to 4Q in 07? Why do you stop in 07?

Yes, the efficiencies of the investments since that time have not yet reached their maturity. When they do, you'll see the amount per employee go up a lot. And yes, this means per employee. In particular, a lot of distribution center employees have been added recently and until they have been through one 4Q at post-investment cycle level margins you won't be able to see the apples to apples comparison.

Because that is what the chart says. Why don't you do your own research and see if it matters? I stop because I made my point. You're welcome to post additional data if you think it adds anything to the discussion.
"I stop because I made my point." Why did you switch from 3Q to 4Q?
Because I knew it would bother the heck out of you.

Message.Title: Motley fool article filled with lies ...
Message.Msg: Namely, that one could take back capex from earnings, once can't and it's stupid to suggest it. That AMZN is plowing earnings into capex is also stupid since many other companies do that without earnings impact as well. And finally, that AMZN still has no debt, which is also a lie - it has both debt and rapidly rising operating leases which are the same as debt.

Topic.Title: Motley fool article filled with lies ...

Message.Msg: "one could take back capex from earnings, once can't" One can do whatever one likes to calculate one's own valuation. This is where you dumb shorts get it wrong. Valuation is not a religion. Companies by law must report GAAP. But many analysts and intelligent investors focus more on non-GAAP metrics in order to gain insights into how they think the company will perform once spending programs are over. This is how you could have realized that the drop to ROIC being cut in half was only temporary and that Amazon would blow away shorts in advance by going from 35 to 90 as ROIC rapidly increased to record levels here: ROIC: 3Q05 __ 44% 3Q06 __ 23% 4Q07 __ 55% "...and it's stupid to suggest it." No, but it is stupid of you to ignore it. I'm sure shorts circa 2005-2006 were just as stupid as you and ignored it as well. ----------- Is Amazon Really That Expensive? http://www.fool.com/investing/general/2012/08/01/is-amazon-really-that-expensive.aspx#.UBmcoI4Ww20

Topic.Title: Motley fool article filled with lies ...

Message.Msg: Article comes with a video. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=U5ACQ4qU_PQ&feature=player_embedded Shorts may wonder why the stock is at such a high PE but 20-30 is not that high which is what the stock trades for in recent times ex-capex. How long do you think Amazon can trade at around PE 25. I think a very, very long time. The important factor is to decide how much of that capex will shrink away once the temporary spending programs are over. The more you think will, the more your valuation would lean towards PE 25 for the recent price ranges. We saw after all how much much of that capex was temporary in the previous investment cycle after all. Shorts claimed that they were all "fixed" costs and would keep Amazon's ROIC halved forever into the future. Yet ROIC more than doubled, proving them wrong: ROIC: 3Q05 __ 44% 3Q06 __ 23% 4Q07 __ 55%

Topic.Title: Amazon, Dangdang and other US-China internet stock pairs

Message.Msg: Dangdang could be another Amazon? Don't wish such a terrible thing on a good Chinese company. AMZN profits have been eroding over the last couple years. Their P/E is already outrageous. They are trying to do what will not work, i.e. become a me-too discount retail brick and mortar store. They cannot beat Walmart at their game. They cannot beat Apple at their game. They cannot even get out of their own way and make more than a tiny profit. When they run out of accounting tricks, and spend the rest of what little cash they have on warehouses and more employees and overhead, they will be in dire straits. Yes, their stock price will keep on ignoring those realities (until they don't). Just remember, they will not ring a bell the day before all hello breaks loose. You amateur retail bagholders will be just that. Go to the new Amazon warehouse and try to get your money back for the $200+ per share stock you foolishly bought becaue all the crooks told you to.
Nice Info
